While Amazon's share in the book market is substantial, it's not the only player.

While you make valid points about Amazon's market dominance, their influence on pricing and exclusivity deals, the increased preference for e-books and the rise of self-publishing, I still maintain that it is an overstatement to claim that "Amazon will kill off publishers".

There is no denying the fact that Amazon has indeed revolutionized the publishing industry and has challenged the traditional publishing model. However, there's an essential point to remember: publishers offer a multitude of services that extend beyond the simple act of selling books - they are involved in the editorial process, in marketing, in publicity, and in market research to better understand readers' tastes. These services are vital for many authors who do not want to (or cannot) handle these aspects of the publishing process.

Moreover, publishers are adapting to the digitization of books and many have developed their own e-book divisions or partnered with other platforms beyond Amazon, diversifying their distribution channels. The physical book market also continues to show resilient consumer demand.

Additionally, with the growth of audiobooks and podcasts, publishers have found yet another avenue to continue their relevance in the literary world.

The claim of "Amazon will kill off publishers" is a simplification of the realities of a constantly evolving industry with many players, not just Amazon. It's more apt to say that 'Amazon is significantly reshaping the publishing industry', which encapsulates the influence Amazon has on the publishing industry while acknowledging that the future of publishing is dynamic and subject to many other contributing factors.
